notes: First-generation Canyon midsize pickup shares GMT355 platform with Chevrolet Colorado and Isuzu i-Series. Available in Z71 Off-Road and ZQ8 Sport suspension packages. Three cab configurations with multiple I4, I5, and V8 engine choices. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Canyon article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Envoy XL extended-wheelbase variant (129 inches, 16 inches longer than standard) designed for third-row seating. GMT360 platform shared with TrailBlazer. 5.3L V8 power increased to 300 hp in 2005. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Envoy article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Unique retractable-roof vehicle inspired by Studebaker Wagonaire. Features midgate system similar to Avalanche and plastic-lined cargo area with drainage. Discontinued after two years due to low sales. Complexity of retractable roof mechanism increases service difficulty. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Envoy article, October 11, 2025 revision.

First-generation Acadia is GMC's first unibody vehicle, replacing Safari van and Envoy. Lambda platform shared with Chevrolet Traverse and Buick Enclave. Denali trim introduced 2011. 2013 facelift with redesigned grille. 5,200 lb towing capacity. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Acadia article, October 11, 2025 revision.

GMT900 Sierra featured redesigned exterior, interior, frame, and suspension with improved aerodynamics. Launched late 2006 as 2007 model. Multiple Vortec engine options with 4-speed or 6-speed automatic transmissions. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Sierra article, October 11, 2025 revision.

First-generation Terrain compact crossover on GM Theta platform. Denali trim added 2013. 2016 mid-cycle refresh with updated styling and LED daytime running lights. Natural gas bi-fuel version available 2013-2014. Engine upgrade from 3.0L to 3.6L V6 in 2013. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Terrain article, October 11, 2025 revision.
